COVID-19 Grand Challenges Africa at AESA

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 African Academy of Sciences (AAS) har hos Sida ansökt om 98,4 miljoner SEK för att genomföra programmet Grand Challenges (GC) Africa under perioden 2018-07-01 till 2023-06-30.
GC Africa är ett program som har målsättningen att stödja innovationer som ska bidra till att hitta lösningar för Afrikas utmaningar med att nå de Globala målen för hållbar utveckling. Det grundläggande konceptet bakom alla GC program är finansiering av innovativa idéer riktade mot specifika frågeställningar utan krav på preliminära resultat. GC Africa placerar konceptet i ett afrikanskt sammanhang och definierar frågeställningar/utmaningar relevanta i den afrikanska kontexten och programmet riktar sig specifikt mot afrikanska forskare verksamma vid universitet och organisationer baserade på den afrikanska kontinenten.
Programmet GC Africa har sin bas på Alliance for Accelerating Excellence in Science in Africa (AESA), ett programinitiativ grundat av AAS och organisationen New Partnership for Africa’s Development med syftet att tackla Afrikas utmaningar inom hälsa och utveckling. AESA har etablerat och driver olika program för att stödja forskare och forskning i Africa samt utveckla akademisk ledarskap och initiativ till innovationer. Sidas avtalspartner kommer att vara AAS, en ny partnerorganisation för Sida.
Den planerade totala budgeten för GC Africa programmet är ca. 246,5 miljoner SEK (28 miljoner USD) varav ca 86,5 miljoner SEK (9,85 miljoner USD) är finansierade av Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur och South African Medical Research Council. AAS har en pågående satsning att hitta fler givare till programmet, bland annat ska afrikanska regeringar och filantroper förmås att bidra. Av Sidas stöd till GC Africa kommer ca. 65,4 miljoner SEK att vidareförmedlas till forskningsprojekt.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The African Academy of Sciences (AAS) has applied to Sida for funding of 98,4 million SEK to contribute to the Grand Challenges (GC) Africa program during the period 2018-07-01 until 2013-06-30.
The GC Africa program aims at supporting the creation of innovations targeting developmental challenges preventing African countries from attaining the Global Goals for Sustainable Development. The basic concept of all GC programs includes grant support to research projects responding to pre-defined challenges not requiring extensive preliminary data. GC Africa has adapted this concept to the African context and established a program open to African researcher based at African universities and institutions and addresses challenges specific to African development needs.
GC Africa is a program of the Alliance for Accelerating Science in Africa (AESA) that is a programmatic platform founded by the AAS and the organization New Partnership for Africa's Development with the aim to address Africa's health and development challenges. AESA has established and drives different programs to support researchers and research projects in Africa and to develop academic leadership and innovations. Sida will enter into agreement with the AAS, a new partner organization for Sida.
The envisaged total budget of the GC Africa program is approximately 246,5 million SEK (28 million USD), out of which 86,5 million SEK (9,85 million USD) have been contributed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Institute Pasteur and the South African Medical Research Council. The AAS is in the process of attracting additional funders to the program and is approaching African governments and philanthropists. Of Sida’s support to the GC Africa program approximately 65,4 million SEK will be forwarded to research projects.

The overall objective of the intervention is to promote Africa-led scientific innovations to help countries better achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by awarding seed and full grants to the continent’s most impressive solutions.

description.narrative: For 2020, Grand Challenges (GC) Africa, a programme of the Alliance for Accelerating Science in Africa (AESA) at the African Academy of Science (AAS), reported three new calls for research and innovation grants: 1) Launch of a Sida-supported proof-of-concept (phase I) call on the topic of Food Security and Nutrition (FSN; https://www.aasciences.africa/calls/grand-challenges-africa-innovation-phase-1-seed-grants-round-12-request-proposals-food). The key areas of this call were i) Ensuring climate resilient food systems, ii) Promote technologies, innovations and agribusinesses to achieve food security and nutrition targets, iii) Address cross-cutting issues that promote food security and nutrition, iv) Achieve the nutrition and health targets of the African Union, and v) Tackle sustainable commercialisation and production of indigenous foods. The call closed in December 2020 and received 269 applications of which 192 are currently undergoing external scientific review. Preparation of the call included stakeholder engagement and an exercise to identify FSN priorities for Africa, and resulted in the drafting of a FSN policy paper. 2) AESA engaged in the response to the COVID-19 pandemic with the organisation of webinars and surveys to define urgent COVID-19 research priorities for Africa. These exercises resulted in the policy papers Research and Development Priorities for COVID-19 in Africa that provided the basis for the research and innovation call Funding for COVID-19 Research & Development Goals for Africa (https://www.aasciences.africa/calls/funding-covid-19-research-development-goals-africa). The call closed in June 2020 and was supported by Sida, Bill and Melinda Gated Foundation (BMGF) and Wellcome Trust. 13 projects were selected for funding. 3) The GC Africa programme also launched its second transition-to-scale (phase II) call and invited innovators to submit proposals with the aim to catalyse scale, support sustainability and promote impact for their projects (https://www.aasciences.africa/calls/grand-challenges-africa-round-11-transition-scale-innovation-call-2). The call received 163 applications of which 63 went into a review and curation process. Applications were evaluated by an independent panel of scientific and business experts, and applicants invited to refine their innovations, scaling strategies and business plans and to prepare detailed budgets with projections and global access strategies. The 19 top-ranked applications were discussed at a decision committee meeting in December 2020, and finally, 13 innovations from Cameroon, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Nigeria, Rwanda, South Africa and Uganda were suggested for funding. The call is supported by Sida and BMGF. In June 2020, the GC Africa programme launched its so-called e-Marketplace for innovators in Africa, the GC Africa innovation Network (GCAiN, http://gcain.africa). GCAiN is a virtual e-based community of practice where innovators, funders, governments, innovation incubators and other partners can have a secluded, safe and confidential space to share ideas, exchange information, support each other and plan for the success of innovations. GCAiN is mainly built to support the transition-to-scale phase of innovations and target groups include African innovators and scientists, funding organizations, philanthropists, governments, venture capitalists and other investors. At its launch, GCAiN had over 300 registered users and the target for 2021 is to reach over 1000 registrations. Major collaborators and funders of the GC Africa programme include BMGF, German Federal Ministry of Education and Research, GC Canada, Sida, South African Medical Research Council, USAID and Wellcome Trust. GC Africa continues to explore partnerships with various African governments to support the launch of national Grand Challenges programmes and has successfully engaged and signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Government of Botswana to form Grand Challenges Botswana (launched in February 2021).
